‘Physical objects are conceptually imported into the situation as convenient intermediaries -- not by definition in terms of experience,
but simply as irreducible posits comparable, epistemologically, to the gods of Homer. Let me interject that for my part I do, qua lay physicist, believe in physical objects and not in Homer's gods; and I consider it a scientific error to believe otherwise. But in point of epistemological footing the physical objects and the gods differ only in degree and not in kind. Both sorts of entities enter our conception only as cultural posits. The myth of physical objects is epistemologically superior to most in that it has proved more efficacious than other myths as a device for working a manageable structure into the flux of experience.’

- Excerpt from Quine’s Two Dogmas

This morning, I shed bittersweet tears as I left NOVA. 

This afternoon, I shed happy tears when I got back to CA. 

Yet the heavy, wet, fat, tears of grief that I shed for the moment in time today that changed women’s and children’s lives as we know them, is weighted on my soul - thick, rusty, stuck, trapped, enslaved to a government that cares more about their egos, profits, and guns than they care about sustainable and efficacious human life. My heart is broken. 

I will not stop crying. I will not stop fighting. I will not stop being angry. I will not stop being a woman who is disgusted at the abhorrent choices made by people who are only motivated by clout, money, and control. F*ck this “democracy.” 

It is time for us to rise and fight especially for those within the system who have been strategically and purposefully punished. Now is the time where community, more than ever, needs to show up.

Alexis de Tocqueville was an improbable prophet of democracy. Born into an aristocratic family, he was brought up in an environment of unquestioning obedience to France’s restored Bourbon monarchy. It was only with the overthrow of Charles X that Tocqueville accepted that the ancien régime was dead. He spent the rest of his life trying to find a middle way between absolutism and revolution. A tour of the United States revealed how bourgeois democracy might function. In The Man Who Understood Democracy, Olivier Zunz asks whether it is right to present him as an uncritical champion of the American democratic experiment, as some – particularly in the United States – have tried to do.

So it begs to question why, when moving in an unknown direction, there is an expectation of perfection… and an ignorant disregard or lack of comprehension that a new experience is unknown territory, where perfection is a dream and not a reality. 

This is exactly why we should fear a world where innovation and creativity are oppressed, and old ideals are revered.  When changes begin, every thought and decision should be actively in the present and moving forward.  The only reason to ever look back is to remember why it was left in the past - and not only to never repeat it, but to use it as a reminder to move forward…

How states will ban or restrict abortions
State laws banning or severely restricting abortion access fall into three broad categories: 1) "trigger bans," which ban abortion under most circumstances and go into effect with the fall of Roe; 2) pre-Roe bans still on the books; and 3) more recent laws that limit abortion to an early gestational age or ban it nearly totally. Some states have laws in more than one of these categories.

Thirteen states have trigger bans, laws that take effect either immediately, by state official certification or after a 30-day waiting period, if Roe is overturned. Once they go into effect, these laws would supersede other laws the state may have on the books, said Elizabeth Nash, a state policy analyst with the Guttmacher Institute.

"The trigger ban applies throughout pregnancy" said Nash. "It does not have a gestational age [restriction]."

Five additional states that don't have trigger laws do have pre-Roe laws banning abortion which could now be applied, depending on state legislative action or judicial enforcement. (Arizona's pre-Roe ban has been on the books since before it became a state.)

Numerous states have passed laws that prohibit abortions after an early gestational age, though trigger bans in most of those states trump these. However, among states without trigger laws, four have six-week bans that could take effect, assuming legal challenges against them are dropped.

Sixteen states and the District of Columbia currently have laws that protect the right to abortion, mostly before the point of fetal viability, according to the nonpartisan Kaiser Family Foundation.

I created multiple paintings like this the same week I made one of the most difficult decisions a person can make in their lifetime—a decision that would have changed the trajectory of my life, indefinitely. 

Our lives are a series of choices. We choose to challenge the beliefs people have of us. We choose to be honest when it’s easier to lie. We choose to eat steak instead of vegetables. We choose to wake up instead of going back to sleep. 

Now, imagine those bigger choices that have the potential to revolutionize your life: like deciding whether to enable a loved one, or cut them out of your life completely; deciding whether you divorce an abuser, or stay unhappily together; deciding whether you move for the job of a lifetime, or stay put out of obligation. 

The only difference between all of these choices and the right to control one’s own body (choosing whether to be fundamentally responsible for the life of another human on this planet) is that the stakes of the former don’t always follow you so far down the road. 

People are going to say this is a Women’s issue. It’s not. If you’ve ever helped a friend/loved one deal with an abortion, then you know it takes support. If you’re a parent who saw your child grow up to fulfill their dreams and live life on their own terms, this one’s for you. If you’ve ever taken your partner to get an abortion, perhaps you’re grateful you weren’t celebrating Father’s Day last week. 

Allowing someone the freedom to make a choice about what they do with their own body is not a luxury, it’s a basic human right. We see people exert that right every day. We can judge them all we want, but we have little recourse when we attempt to block them from those decisions. And we like it that way. 

DO NOT GET IT WRONG: this decision will negatively affect people that matter dearly to you, in one way or another, for years to come. 

And if you still think you don’t know someone who has gotten an abortion, rest assured they just haven’t told you yet.
